DIV1.HEAD: Die mittelenglische Sprichwörtersammlung in Douce 52.
DIV1.AB:
1
He þat doth as can,
Blame hym no man.
Non est culpandus faciens quod scit, sed amandus.

DIV2.HEAD: De hac litera D.
DIV2.AB:
2
He þat a lytul me ȝeuyth, to me wyllyth longe lyffe.
Qui modicum mihi dat, mihi vitam longius optat.

3
Ȝefe me and I the,
And so schul we frendus be.
Des mihi demque tibi; sic nos iungemur amici.

4
Oft bryngeth on day, 4. Rawlinson-Prov. (Engl. Stud. XXI 16): On dai bringd, thet al ier ne mai; J. Heywood's Proverbs, 1546 (ed. Sharman S. 67): It hapth in one houre, that hapth not in seven yeare.
Þat all þe ȝere not may.
Sepe dat vna dies, fert1 annus quod nequeLies ferre und nequit (Bradley). vnus.

5
Better is herde sorow þan seen.
Est dolor auditu tollerabilior tibi visu.

6
Euer is my tonge, þer the toth akys.
Quo dolor est dentis, versatur lingua dolentis.

7
Ferre jfet and dere j-bowȝt is goode for ladys. 7. J. Heywood S. 67: Deare bought and far fet are dainties for Ladies; Lyly's Euphues, 1579 (ed. Arber p. 93): Farre fet and deere bought is good for Ladyes; Stubbs, Anatomy of Abuses, 1583 (Oxf. Dict.): Farre fetched and deare boughte is good for Ladyes; J. Marston, Malcontent, 1604 (bei Sharman): Some far fet trick, good for ladies; Beaumont & Fletcher, Wit at Several Weapons, 1647 (bei Sharman): Far fetched; therefore good for you, lady; De∣foe, Tour Gr. Brit., 1769 (Oxf. Dict.): Farfetch'd, and dear bought, is fittest for the Ladies.
Res longe lata bene fit dominabus amata.

8
After mete disshes ben rybeLies rive (H. Bradley)..
Crebrescunt vacui certe post prandia disci.

9
Helpe God and haue alle 9. Vgl. Havelock 648: Þer God wile helpen, nouht ne dereth (?).
Det Deus auxilium, fiat et omne suum.

10
At euene prayse þe fayre day. 10. Hendyng, Cambr. Hs. Nr. 34: At eve man scal þe dai heri und Oxf.|Hs. Nr. 33: At even me shal preisen þe feire dai.
Vespere detur ei, si laus sit danda diei.

11
Seldun comyth on harme and no mo.

12
Who is ferre from his disshe, is nyhgh his harme.

13
Blessyd be þe peny, þat bryngyth too home.

14
Of a litul me ȝeuyth a litul.

15
The nere the chyrche, þe fer fro Crist. 15. J. Heywood S. 35: The neer to the church, the further from God.

DIV2.HEAD: De hac litera E.
DIV2.AB:
16
Spende, and God wyl sende; 16. J. Heywood S. 115 nur: Ever spare, and ever bare.
Spare, and euere bare.
Expendas late, mittet Deus omnia grate.

17
Short hors is son j-curryed. 17. J. Heywood S. 39: A short horse is soone currid.
Sufficit exiguo strigilatio curta caballo.

18
Euer lenger, þe wors lokys þe blynde hors.
Semper cecus equus spectat peius et puto peius.

19
Who-so wyl abyde, 19. Alisaundre V. 4291: He that can his tyme abide, Ofte he schal his wille betyde. Vgl. Hendyng Harl.-Hs. Nr. 31: Wel abit, þat wel may þolye und Oxf. Hs. Nr. 41: Muchel of his wille abit, þat wel may þolien (Kneuer S. 23).
He schal wel be-tyde.

20
While þe grasse growes, þe goode hors sterues. 20. Capgrave, Life of St. Katherine, ca. 1440 (Oxf. Dict.): The gray hors, whyl his gras growyth, May sterue for hunger; R. Hilles, Common∣Place Book, ca. 1530 (Oxf. Dict.): Whyle the grasse growyth, the hors stervyth;J. Heywood S. 64: While the grasse groweth, the horse starveth; Whetstone, Promos and Cassandra, 1578 (bei Malone und Sharman): Whylst grass doth growe, oft sterves the seely steede; Harl. Ms. 2321 (16. Jh. = Reliquiae An∣tiquae I 208): While the grasse growes, the steede starves; The Paradise of Daintie Devises, 1578 (Malone): While grass doth growe, the silly horse he starves; Shakspere, Hamlet III 2, 327: I sir, but 'while the grasse growes',—the prouerbe is something musty (Q2).

21
Who-so goth to chirch aȝenst his will, he comyth home acursyd.

22
When þe hors is stole, steke þe stabull-dore.22. J. Heywood S. 44: When the steede is stolne, shut the stable durre; Devises of Sundrie Gentlemen (bei Sharman): The steede was stollen, before I shut the gate.

23
While þe hors kykys, war that he the ne smyte.

24
Hit is better not to be, than not to well beVielleicht well to be?.
Prestat non esse, quam non feliciter esse.

25
Who-so byldeth after euery man his howse, hit schall stonde a-croke.

26
Kepe þe fro care,
And blesse þe fro þe mare.

DIV2.HEAD: De hac litera F.
DIV2.AB:
27
Who-so sparyth to speke, sparyth to spede.27. J. Heywood S. 67: Spare to speak, spare to speed.

28
Hungur brekyth stone and walle.28. J. Heywood S. 82: Hunger pearceth stone wall; Shakspere, Corio∣lanus I 1, 210: Hunger broke stone-walls; Topsell Serpents, 1608 (Oxf. Dict.): Hunger breaketh stone-walls.

29
Hungur makyth harde benys swete.29. J. Heywood S. 50: Hunger maketh hard beans sweet.

30
Welle were hym, þatLies þat wist. to wham he myȝhty ist aus ȝ verbessert. trist, 30. Aschmole Ms. 1438 (XV. Jh.) II p. 82 (Catal. Codd. Mss. Bodleianae P. X 1845): Wel were hym, þat wyst, / to wham he moght trist / yn tyme off nede: / Beter were he, þat knew / the falce fro the trew / clothyd yn oon wede.
And so were hym, þat knew false fro þe trewe.
Est bene, qui noscet, in quo confidere quiretProf. P. Wolters schlägt vor, wegen noscet hier posset zu lesen..
Felix qui sciret, in quo confidere quiret;
Sic et qui fidumLies infidum (H. Bradley). cognorouerit et modo fidum.

31
Euyl spunnun ȝerne comyth euyll oute.31. Hendyng, Harl.-Hs. Nr. 34: Euer out comeþ euel sponne web, Oxf.-Hs. Nr. 37: Evere comeþ out uvel sponnen wolle, Cambr.-Hs. Nr. 39: Ever comith out liþre spon web; Towneley Mysteries II 435: Ill spon weft ay comes foul out; How the Wise Man taught his Son V. 7 f.: But ȝarn that is oft-tyme yll sponne, Euyll hyt comys out at the last.

32
Do welle and haue welle. 32. J. Heywood S. 153: Doe well and have well.

33
RodunWohl mit H. Bradley in Bodun zu verbessern. seruycys stynkys. 33. Chaucer, Cant. Tales G 1066: Profred servyse stynketh (Haeckel S. 47); J. Heywood S. 105.: Proferd service stinketh.
Omnibus oblatus sordere solet famulatus.

34
Welle worth alle-moost done.
Res bene laudatur; cum ferme perficatur.

35
Ese makyth thefe. 35. Hali Meidenhad S. 17: Eise makeđ þeof.

36
On betyth þe buske, a-noþer hatheLies hath the. brydde. 36. Ipomadon V. 6021 f.: On the bushe bettes one, A-nothere man hath the bryde; Gower, Conf. Am. II 2355 f: He... takth the bridd to his beyete, Wher othre men the buisshes bete; Lydgate, Falls of Princes I 14, 41: One beateth the bush, another hath the sparrow; Generides V. 4524: Some bete the bussh, and some the byrdes take; J. Heywood S. 13: While I ... beate the bush, ... other men ... catch the burdes; H. Pettowe, Philochasander and Elanira, 1599 (bei Sharman): I beat the bush, and others catch the bird.

37
Yf þou wylle hole be, lete all frute be.

38
Þe last worde byndeth þe tale. 38. Sarmun, ab. 1300, V. 211 (Early English Poems, ed. Furnivall, S. 6 = Mätzner Sprachproben I 119): þe last word bint þe tale.

DIV2.HEAD: [G].
DIV2.AB:
39
A cock were a feyre fowle, nere he wherewhere ist zu streichen. ofte j-seyn.

40
All hit is for wo,
Þat þe hen synges in snowe.

41
Þe grace of God is better þen III feyrys.
Gratia diuina valet vltra quam fora bina.

42
Þe tonge brekyth bon 42. Siehe meine Zusammenstellungen Engl. Stud. XXXI 6.
And hath hym-selfe non.

43
As þe cocke croweth, so þe chekyn lernyth. 43. J. Heywood S. 39: The yong cocke croweth, as he the old heareth; Barclay, Shyp of Folys, 1570 (Oxf. Dict.): The yonge Cocke lerneth to crow hye of the olde; Puttenham, English Poesie (Arber S. 199): As the olde cocke crowes, so doeth the chick.

44
Thow hast bore þe welle.
Tu bene gessisti seu te bene nunc habuisti.

45
Spele Frenssh and construe art,
And þou schalt selde com to thy part.

46
He was neuer wyse,
Þat went on þe yse.

47
A scalde mannys hede is lefe to breke. 47. Harl.-Ms. 3362 (Ende 15. Jh.): A scallyd mannys hed ys good to be broke—Frangitur ex facili caput infantis glabriosi; J. Heywood S. 103: A scald head is soone broken.

48
Who-so comyth late to his in, schall erly for-thynke. 48. Vgl. J. Heywood S. 168: He that commeth last to the pot, is soonest wroth.

49
Better is worship then þe full wombe.

DIV2.HEAD: De hac litera I.
DIV2.AB:
50
Fayre and softe me ferre gose.

51
Where no fyre, is no smoke. 51. J. Heywood S. 120: No fire without some smoke.

52
Brende chylde fyre dredis. 52. Hendyng, Cambr.-Hs. Nr. 22: Brande [Brend Harl. u Oxf.] childe fire [fur Harl, fuir Oxf.] dredit [dredeþ Harl., fordredeþ Oxf.]; Michel of Northgate, Ayenbite S. 116: Þe ybernde uer dret: Chaucer, Rom. Rose V. 1820: Brent child of fier hath myche drede; Lydgate, Chorl and Bird Nr. 26: Brent childe dredethe fire; J. Heywood S 94: Burnt child fire dredth; Coverdale, Spir. Perle, 1550 (Oxf. Dict.): A burnt hande dreadeth the fire; Timon, ca. 1590 (ed. Dyce S. 89; bei Sharman): A burnt childe dreads the ffyre; Lauderdale Papers, 1674 (Oxf. Dict.): A burn'd child dreads the fire.

53
Vnbodun gest not, where he shall sytte.
Ignorat sedem non inuitatus ad edem.

54
Hit is mery a manHs. aman. to syt by his owne fyre.

55
Of a lytul sparkull comyth a grete fyre. 55. Burgh's Cato V. 449: Off brandis smale be maad thes fires grete.

56
A man, wote, when he goes; but he wote not, when he comys.

57
As long leuyth a mery man as a sory. 57. D. Lyndesay, Sat. 105 f.: For as lang leifis the mirrie man, As the sorie (Kissel Nr. 49).

DIV2.HEAD: De litera L.
DIV2.AB:
58
When game is best, 58. Proverbis of Wysdom V. 50 (15. Jh.), ed. Zupitza in Archiv f. d. Stud. d. n. Sprach. XC 241 ff.: When game is best, is tyme to lete.
Hit is tyme to rest.

59
Lothe to bedde and lothe fro bedde me schall know þe slow.

60
I wyll prayse my-selfe, syn no manHs. noman. ellys wyll.

61
Holde þy tonge and holde þy frende. 61. Chaucer, Cant. Tales I 319: Keepe wel thy tonge and keepe thy freend; Peter Idle, Instructions to his Son (ed. Miesner, Greifswald 1903) V. 335: Kepe thy tonge and kepe thy frende.

62
Who-so hath an euyll tonge,
Euer he spekyth, that is wrong.

63
By the litul welpys me chastys þe lyon. 63. Chaucer, Cant. Tales F 490: By the whelpe chasted is the leoun; G. Herbert, Jacula Prudentum, vor 1640 (Skeat's Chaucer V 384): Beat the dog before the lion; Shakspere, Othello II 3, 272: even so as one would beat his offenceless dog to affright an imperious lion.

64
Do thow better, do thow worse, 64. J. Heywood S. 21 nur: Doe you after him, that beareth the purse.
Do after hym, that beryth the purse.

DIV2.HEAD: De hac litera M.
DIV2.AB:
65
Mykull wulle more.

66
On begger is wo, þat anothir in to þe towne goth. 66. Taverner, Erasmus' Proverbs, 1552 (Oxf. Dict.): One begger byddeth wo, that another by the dore shuld go.

67
TheBradley schlägt Ther für The vor. schall no manHs. noman. bete ne bynde a messyngLies messynger..
Non decet artare, qui mittitur, atLies aut. religare.

68
Erly mayster, longe knaue. 68. Prouerbis of Wysdom V. 38: To erly mayster, the sonner knave.

70
Many hondys makyn lyȝthLies lyȝt. worke. 70. Sir Beues V. 3012: Many handes make lyght warke; How the Goode Wife taught hir Daughter (15. Jh.) V. 115: Many handys make light werke; J. Heywood S. 114: Many hands make light warke; Taverner, Erasmus' Prov., 1552 (Oxf. Dict.): Many handes make a lyghte burthen; F. Hawkins, Youth's Behaviour, 1663 (Oxf. Dict.): Many hands make light work.

71
He comys not to late,
Þat any gode is y-shape.
Non mora fit dura, bona cui sunt vlla futura.

72
Seldun getes þe dom man gode. 72. Digby Ms. 53 (Engl. Stud. XXXI 15): Selden gifis men dumb man land (13. Jh.); Rawl. A 273 (a. a. O.): Seld men gyfth a dumbe man lond.

73
He is as clene, as cattus hadde lykkyd hym.

74
I kepe no more but the skyn of the catt. 74. Vgl. J. Heywood S. 162: Hee can have no more of the foxe but the skin.

75
For the lesse me lefus the more.

76
Who-so nouȝt dois, nouȝt seruyth. 76. Vgl. Chaucer, Cant. Tales B 1820: Yvele shal have, that yvele wol deserve.
Nil homini detur, qui nil sudans operetur.

77
Maner makys man. 77. Prouerbis of Wysdom V. 59: Euer maner and clothyng makyth man, und dazu Zupitzas reiche Nachweise auf S. 254. Ausserdem Barclay, Shyp of Folys, 1509 (Oxf. Dict.): Maners makyth man; W. de Worde's Druck von Lydgate's Horse, Goose and Sheep, Appendix (ed. Degenhardt S. 14 Nr. 2): Manner maketh man.

78
Welle wotes the catte, whoos berder über der Zeile. he lykkys. 78. Siehe meine Nachweise Engl. Stud. XXXI 7. [P. Meyer weist Ro∣mania XXXI 477 einen neuen Beleg für badde 'Katze' nach: in der Fabel von der Katze und den Mäusen bei Nicolas Bozon (Contes Moralisés p. 144 f.) heisst die Katze Sire Badde].

79
Hit is harde to lykke hony fro the thorne. 79. Vgl. Ureisun, ca. 1240 (Oxf. Dict.): Huni þer-in beoþ liked of þornes.

80
Dere is þe hony bouȝt, 80. Hendyng, Cambr.-Hs. Nr. 33: Al to dere his bouht honni To like up hauh þorne, Harl.-Hs. Nr. 30: Dere is boht þe honey, þat is licked of þe þorne, Oxf.-Hs. Nr. 22: Al to dere is bouht honi, þat mon shal liken of þornes. (Kneuer 43 f.)
Þat on thornes is souȝt.

81
Mesure is tresureDies Sprichwort ist zweimal geschrieben: fol. 24a unten und fol. 24b oben. 81. Lydgate, Minor Poems p. 82: Mesoure is tresoure; Burgh's Cato V. 505: The olde sawe seithe 'Mesure is tresur'; Seager's Schoole of Vertue (1557) V. 477 f. (Furnivall's Babees Book p. 344): For 'measure is treasure' the prouerbe doth say.

82
Seldun comyth lone lauȝyng home. 82. Hendyng, Cambr.-Hs. Nr. 23: Selde [Selden Oxf.] comit [comeþ Oxf. u. Harl.] lone lechind [lahynde H, lauinde O] home [homward O], (Kneuer 37). Vgl. Harl. Ms. 2321 (16. Jh. = Rel. Ant. I 208): When I lent, I was a frend; When I asked, I was unkinde.

83
Sore I syke and well I may
For thre thyngis, þat comyn ay.
Þe fyrstDies Sprichwort ist zweimal geschrieben: fol. 24a unten und fol. 24b oben. is: I schall hen;
Þe secunde: I not neuer when;
Þe thrydde is most care:
I not nere, whidur I schall fare.
Sunt tria vere, que faciunt me sepe dolere.
Est primum durum, quia nosco me moriturum;
Atque sequens plango magis, quia nescio quando.
Inde magis flebo, quia nescio quo remanebo.

84
Muche he has, þat wylle no more.

DIV2.HEAD: De hac litera N.
DIV2.AB:
85
Kynde crepus, ther hit may noWohl für nördl. na stehend. go. 85. J. Heywood S. 58: Kinde will creepe where it may not goe; Shak∣spere, Two Gentlemen IV 2, 20: Love will creep in service where it cannot go.

DIV2.HEAD: De hac litera O.
DIV2.AB:
86
The more hast, þe worse spede. 86. J. Heywood S. 8: The more haste, the lesse speede. Vgl. Barbour's Troybook II 1682 (Oxf. Dict.): Of fule haist cummis no speid; Chaucer, Troi∣lus I 956: He hasteth wel, that wisly can abide (dazu Haeckel Nr. 83-85).

87
Oon scabbyd shepe makyth a fowle flock.

88
The pot goth so longe to water, þat he comyth broke home. 88. Knight of La Tour-Landry (ed. Wright EETS 33): The potte may goo so longe to water, that atte the laste it is broken; J. Heywood S. 142: The pot so long to the water goth, Till at last it commeth home broken; Greene, Never too Late, 1590 (bei Sharman): For so long went the pot to the water, that at last it came broken home.

89
Seldun sey, sone for-ȝete. 89. Vernon-Ms. (Varnhagen, Anglia VII 281): Þat selden iseiȝe is sone forȝete; Prouerbis of Wysdom V. 25: Seld i-say ys sone for-yete; Harl.-Ms. 3362: Zelde yseyȝe, sone forȝete; Political Songs & Poems ed. Wright I 215: Selden iseiȝe is sone forgete; J. Heywood S. 52: Seldom seene, soone forgotten. Vgl. Proverbs of Alfred Nr. 27 (nur Jesus-Hs.): For he, þat is ute biloken, he is inne sone for-geten.

90
That, atVielleicht in that zu bessern oder als Dittographie zu streichen; doch vgl. S. 41. is swete in thy mummeLies munne (H. Bradley).,
Geue thy felawe summe.
Da partem socio, quod sapit ore tuo.

DIV2.HEAD: De hac litera P.
DIV2.AB:
91
When bale is heystLies hext, 91. Siehe Zupitzas Verweise auf Hendyng (Kneuer 35), Owl and Night∣ingale 685 u. 697, Cursor Mundi 4775, Testament of Love II ch. 9, I. 143, Babees Book 119, 32, Heywood S. 81 und Sir Aldingar 111 (Percy's Fol. Ms.) in Arch. XC 249.
Bote is next.

92
Who-so may not go byfore, com by-hynde.

93
Alle to late, alle to late, 93. Hendyng, Cambr.-Hs. Nr. 47: Al to late, al to late, Wan þe deth is at þe ȝate: Poema Morale V. 127: Þanne deđ is et þere dure, wel late he biddeđ are (Lewin).
When deth is come to ȝate.

94
Lytyll may helpe, þere myche be-houeth.

95
When þe slowe is full, þen þe chare is done.
Cum piger impletur, operis tunc finis habetur.

96
Ofte drynke maketh þy wyttes renne.

97
So brewe, so drynke. 97. Hendyng, Cambr.-Hs. Nr. 17: First sour brewit, sit sour drinkit (Kneuer 31); Cursor Mundi V. 2848: Suilk als þei brucd, now ha þai dronken; Gower, Conf. Am. III. 1626 f: And who-so wicked ale breweth, Fulofte he mot the werse drinke; Political Poems, 1451 (Oxf. Dict.): Let hem drynk as they hanne brewe; Heywood S. 31: As I would needes brewe, so must I nee∣des drinke; Pasquil's Night-cap, 1612 (Oxf. Dict.): You must drinke as you have bru'd; Wodroephe, Spared Houres, 1623 (bei Sharman): If you have browen wel, you shal drinke the better. Anspielung darauf bei Chaucer, House of Fame III 790.

98
Holde þy thombe in thi fyst, 98. Prouerbis of Wysdom V. 90: Euer be ware of 'Had I wyst' und Zupitzas reiche Nachweise zu dieser Stelle. Ausserdem Peter Idle, Instructions to his Son, ca 1420 (ed. Miesner, Greifswald 1903) V. 83: Kepe cloos all thyng, as thombe in fiste, And euer beware of 'Hadd y wyste'.
And kepe þe welle fro 'Had I wyst'.

99
The smaller pesun, the more to pott; 99. Sloane-Ms. 1210, fol. 134a (15. Jh. = Rel. Ant. II 40): Tho [lies The] smallere pese, tho mo to the pott; Tho fayrere woman, tho more gyglott; The Schole-House of Women, 1561, V. 558 f. (ed. Halliwell, E. E. P. IV 126): The smaller pease, the mo to the pot; The fairer woman, the more gillot; Heywood S. 20 nur: Who hath many pease, may put the mo in the pot.
The fayrer woman, the more gylott.

100
Lefe chylde lore be-houeth. 100. Hendyng, Harl.-Ms. Nr. 5: Luef [Lef O] child lore byhoueþ [bihoveþ lore O], Cambr.-Hs. Nr. 3: Lothe childe behovid lore And leve childe som del more; Goode Wife taught hir Doughter V. 160: Leue childe lore be∣houeth; Symon's Lesson of Wysedome V. 88 (Furnivall's Babees Book p. 402): A leve chyld, lore he be-houyth.

101
Thow shall do, as þe preste says, but not as þe preste doos.

102
Couenaunt is auenaunt.

103
Better is a ȝongHs. aȝong. chylde wepe than an olde man. 103. Heywood S. 59: Better children weepe then old men.

104
Of a raggud colte comes a gode hors. 104. Heywood S. 58: Of a ragged colt there comth a good horse; Eastward Hoe, 1605 (bei Sharman): The ragged colt may prove a good horse.

105
The better þou be þeDies þe ist offenbar vor bese zu stellen., 105. Hendyng, Harl.-Hs. Nr. 20: þe [So þe O] bet þe be, þe [so þe O] bet þe byse [bise O]; Owl and Nightingale V. 1267: Evereuch man the bet him beo, Eaver the bet he hine beseo.
The better be-se.

106

DIV1.P: Anhangsweise seien hier noch einige englische Sprichwörter und Ähnliches zusammengestellt, die sich in dem anglofranzösischen Text der Exempelsammlung des in England tätigen Franziskaners Nicolas Bozon (ca. 1320) eingestreut finden. Der Urtext dieser Contes moralisés (ed. T. Smith et P. Meyer, Paris 1889) ist in zwei Handschriften (in Gray's Inn und zu Cheltenham) überliefert, die beide aus der Mitte des 14. Jahrhunderts stammen; während die teilweise Übersetzung des Werkes ins Lateinische, wie sie im Harl. Ms. 1288 vorliegt, in das Ende desselben Jahrhunderts gehört. In das 14. Jahrhundert ist mithin auch das Englisch der nachfolgenden Sprüche zu verlegen. Wo y für þ steht, habe ich bei meinem Abdruck letzteres eingesetzt, ebenso in Nr. 1 und 9 ȝ statt z gebraucht.

Als wirkliche Sprichwörter sind eigentlich wohl nur vier derselben, Nr. 1. 3. 4. 9, anzusprechen; vielleicht außerdem noch Nr. 7. Die übrigen, namentlich Nr. 5 und 8, könnten wohl—worauf schon die Herausgeber hingewiesen haben—aus ver∣lorenen englischen Fabelversionen stammen, die Bozon als Vor∣lage gedient hätten. Nr. 10 mag in letzter Linie auf Jesaias I 22 Argentum tuum versum est in scoriam; vinum tuum mixtum est aqua zurückgehen.
